text.author: Santa Barbara Corpus of Spoken American English (ed. John W. Du Bois)
text.title: Shaggy Dog Story
text.summary1: (human1) The owner of some paintings shows them to someone and tells how his wife fell in love with art by Jewish Mexican artist Leonardo Nierman on a trip to Mexico twenty five years ago, where they bought a painting of a Mexican woman with a watermelon on her head for $30, and recounts how his father-in-law bought him his first piece of art, by Geri Rae, for his office.
text.summary2: (claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022) During a trip to Mexico City 25 years ago, the speaker recalls exploring art galleries and being interested in two Jewish artists - Nierman's expensive paintings that his wife loved and LeRoy Neiman's sports artwork.
text.summary3: (gpt4o; postedited) A person reminisces about a trip to Mexico City where his wife Rae was enamored with a Mexican artist named Nierman, although he was hesitant to spend a significant amount on art, and recalls the city's vibrant art scene, the cab rides, and his enjoyable and inexpensive painting purchases, juxtaposed with his later discovery of LeRoy Neiman's sports art in a gallery.
text.summary4: (Meta-Llama-3-8B-Instruct; postedited) The speaker recounts his 25-year-old story of visiting Mexico City with his wife and friends, where they saw an artist named Nierman, who was a Mexican national, and his paintings, which were very inexpensive.
text.summary5: (Qwen2.5-7B-Instruct) During a trip to Mexico City with family, the narrator encountered two different Mexican artists, LeRoy Neiman (a sports artist) and Leonardo Nierman (an art colony member), whose works initially seemed too expensive for the narrator's tastes despite being intrigued by them.
